newsitem.title: USA: White House denies any change of Iran policy.
newsitem.headline: White House denies any change of Iran policy.

text.p: The White House said on Sunday that U.S. efforts to isolate fundamentalist Iran remained unchanged despite a decision not to oppose a huge natural gas pipeline that would feed Iranian coffers.
"There's been no change in policy," said Anne Luzzato, a spokeswoman for President Clinton. "There's been no signal regarding our policy to Iran."

The United States has determined that it had no grounds under law for opposing the pipeline, which would carry gas from Turkmenistan on the eastern side of the Caspian Sea across a 788-mile stretch of northern Iran to Turkey and eventually to Europe.
"We have determined that the ILSA (the 1996 Iran-Libya Sanctions Act) does not apply to this particular arrangement," Luzzato said.
She said the administration would continue to apply that law, which bars U.S. and foreign invesments of more than $40 million in the development of Iran's energy sector.
U.S. policy remained committed to denying Iran the resources needed to bankroll what the United States regards as its role in state-sponsored terrorism, the spokeswoman added.
The 2,000-mile (3,219 km) pipeline project would mark Iran's first participation in any major international energy project since the 1979 Islamic revolution.
Iran would receive transit fees for allowing the gas to flow across its territory.
